results.title: Morris loves Jack
results.brief_description: An off-beat romance between a policewoman and the charming but feckless unemployed actor who shares her house and her money. She is happy to support him emotionally and financially, in spite of his irresponsible attitude to life until she finds him in the arms of “another”. Cast includes Kris McQuade, John Hargreaves, Bill Hunter, David Boyd.

results.title: Morris loves Jack
results.brief_description: A star studded short drama, Morris Loves Jack is an off-beat romance between Jack, a young policewoman and Morris, the charming but feckless out of work actor who shares her house and her money. She is happy to support him emotionally and financially in spite of his irresponsible attitude to life until she finds him in the arms of another. Starring Kris McQuade and John Hargraves

results.title: Morris's disappearing bag (K)
results.creator_credit: Michael Sporn, Morton Schindel and Weston Woods Studios
results.brief_description: An animated children’s story in which Morris receives a bag, for Christmas, which can make him disappear. Based on the book by Rosemary Wells.

results.title: Morpho
results.brief_description: A surrealistic experimental film on the elusive butterfly of love, where time passes in surrealistic images. Music by Enrico de Pietro. Design: John Stoddart. Camera: J. Luscombe. No other credits available.

results.title: Morocco
results.brief_description: The Foreign Legion marches into Mogador with booze and women in mind just as singer Amy Jolly arrives from Paris to work at Lo Tinto’s cabaret. That night, insouciant legionnaire Tom Brown catches her inimitably seductive, tuxedo-clad act.

constellations_other.name: Wearing the pants, ladies who lead
constellations_other.description: The pre-code 1932 feature, A Bill of Divorcement, a glass cinema slide of which features in the glass cinema slide display, stars John Barrymore and Katharine Hepburn in her screen debut.

results.description: The Foreign Legion marches in to Mogador with booze and women in mind just as singer Amy Jolly arrives from Paris to work at Lo Tinto’s cabaret. That night, insouciant legionnaire Tom Brown catches her inimitably seductive, tuxedo-clad act. Both bruised by their past lives, the two edge cautiously into a no-strings relationship while being pursued by others. But Tom must leave on a perilous mission: is it too late for them?
description_for_label: The Foreign Legion marches in to Mogador with booze and women in mind just as singer Amy Jolly arrives from Paris to work at Lo Tinto’s cabaret. That night, insouciant legionnaire Tom Brown catches her inimitably seductive, tuxedo-clad act. Both bruised by their past lives, the two edge cautiously into a no-strings relationship while being pursued by others. But Tom must leave on a perilous mission: is it too late for them?

results.title: Moro: Melanesian bigman
results.creator_credit: Graham Chase, Don Murray and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Solomon Islands”.
Moro and his people live on the island of Guadalcanal in the central Solomons. Some see him as a ‘cult leader’ and others ‘a confused power hungry man’. But to the people of the Solomon Island he is a real Melanesian Bigman who has rejected the use of modern technology. Cinematographer: Dean Semler. Narrated by Alfred Aihunu.

results.title: Morning paper
results.creator_credit: Donald Carter, H. Bruce Woolfe and Gaumont-British Instructional
results.brief_description: The story of a newspaper during wartime. Shows how the news is gathered and prepared for the press in spite of the threat of bombs. Describes the composition and checking of the pages, the creation of curved steroes to fit the rotary presses and various other tasks that must be completed before the paper can be put to bed.

results.title: Morning on the Lievre
results.creator_credit: David Bairstow, Guy Glover and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Poet Archibald Lampman describes in verse the dazzling beauty of Quebec’s Lievre River as it winds past maple-wooded hills in late September. Every tree is ablaze with colour, and the riot of reds, golds and greens is caught and held in the mirror surfaces of the water. In “Morning on the Lievre” you see the river through the poet’s eyes. Sole accompaniment is the reading of the poem, and music specially composed. (Awards: Eight including Edinburgh; Boston; Brussels)
